articles.headline: Devastated Democrats Play the Blame Game, and Stare at a Dark Future
articles.snippet: In interviews, lawmakers and strategists tried to explain Kamala Harris’s defeat, pointing to misinformation, the Gaza war, a toxic Democratic brand and the party’s approach to transgender issues.
articles.abstract: In interviews, lawmakers and strategists tried to explain Kamala Harris’s defeat, pointing to misinformation, the Gaza war, a toxic Democratic brand and the party’s approach to transgender issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: A depressed and demoralized Democratic Party is beginning the painful slog into a largely powerless future, as its leaders grapple with how deeply they underestimated Donald J. Trump’s resurgent hold on the nation.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein, Lisa Lerer and Nicholas Nehamas

articles.headline: Trump Agenda Faces a Fiscal Reckoning
articles.snippet: Advisers to President-elect Donald J. Trump and Republicans on Capitol Hill are already looking at ways to scale back some of his more expensive ideas.
articles.abstract: Advisers to President-elect Donald J. Trump and Republicans on Capitol Hill are already looking at ways to scale back some of his more expensive ideas.
articles.lead_paragraph: No tax on tips? Lower corporate taxes? No tax on Social Security benefits?

articles.headline: How Russia Openly Escalated Its Election Interference Efforts
articles.snippet: The Kremlin did not bother to hide its efforts to influence the 2024 presidential election, as it did in the past.
articles.abstract: The Kremlin did not bother to hide its efforts to influence the 2024 presidential election, as it did in the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the final days before Tuesday’s vote, Russia abandoned any pretense that it was not trying to interfere in the American presidential election.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Companies Brace for the Return of Trump’s Old Trade Gripes
articles.snippet: The president-elect is again calling out companies by name in his campaign against what he sees as other countries’ unfair practices.
articles.abstract: The president-elect is again calling out companies by name in his campaign against what he sees as other countries’ unfair practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump repeatedly singled out the Japanese construction equipment maker Komatsu during his 2016 presidential campaign, employees at the company were taken aback.
articles.byline: By River Akira Davis, Daisuke Wakabayashi, Alex Travelli and Meaghan Tobin

articles.headline: Antisemitic Attacks Prompt Emergency Flights for Israeli Soccer Fans
articles.snippet: Dutch and Israeli officials said the fans had been attacked in Amsterdam after tensions flared around an Israeli team’s visit.
articles.abstract: Dutch and Israeli officials said the fans had been attacked in Amsterdam after tensions flared around an Israeli team’s visit.
articles.lead_paragraph: The authorities in Amsterdam on Friday were investigating what they called antisemitic attacks on Israeli soccer fans that took place amid a charged atmosphere surrounding a soccer match involving a visiting Israeli team.
articles.byline: By John Yoon, Christopher F. Schuetze, Jin Yu Young and Claire Moses

articles.headline: What a Second Trump Term Could Mean for Your Money
articles.snippet: Here’s what the president-elect has said he might do with your taxes, student loans, Social Security and more.
articles.abstract: Here’s what the president-elect has said he might do with your taxes, student loans, Social Security and more.
articles.lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump made a number of personal finance promises during his presidential campaign. How many will he try to — and be able to — keep?
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: How My War Came Home
articles.snippet: A reporter thought of his city in the west of Ukraine as a haven from Russian bombs — until a strike hit his street.
articles.abstract: A reporter thought of his city in the west of Ukraine as a haven from Russian bombs — until a strike hit his street.
articles.lead_paragraph: I’ve covered the brutal realities of Ukraine’s war on its eastern front lines since the Russian invasion of 2022, but my home on the other side of the country remained largely untouched by violence.

articles.headline: California Shifts Rightward on Crime in an Election Fueled by Frustration
articles.snippet: Voters in the Democratic-run state overwhelmingly approved a measure to impose harsher sentences for crimes and were on their way to ousting two progressive district attorneys.
articles.abstract: Voters in the Democratic-run state overwhelmingly approved a measure to impose harsher sentences for crimes and were on their way to ousting two progressive district attorneys.
articles.lead_paragraph: California is known for having some of the most progressive laws in the country. But in Tuesday’s election, the state lurched rightward, as voters sent a clear message that they were fed up with crime and homelessness in their state.

articles.headline: With Trump Tariffs Looming, Businesses Try to ‘Run From a Moving Target’
articles.snippet: Companies are filling their warehouses or looking into moving factories as they weigh President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threats to impose tariffs on foreign goods.
articles.abstract: Companies are filling their warehouses or looking into moving factories as they weigh President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threats to impose tariffs on foreign goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rick Muskat woke up the morning after the election with an urgent task. He got his agent in China on the phone at 4:30 a.m. Beijing time and pressed him to ask their factory how many more pairs of men’s dress shoes they could make before Chinese New Year, at the end of January.
